body: When I was growing up in India, a career in the civil service was considered to be one of the most prestigious careers one could go into. From a young age, I remember my parents and teachers pushing me towards it as the career choice. This was not in a controlling sense, but because they wanted the best for me and a job in the Indian public sector was just that: one of the most highly respected across society. Like a typical youngster I decided against my parents’ advice and instead embarked on a career as an entrepreneur. This has taken me on a journey, not only from India to the UK, but to organisations such as Shazam and BCG Digital Ventures, via the Arts Council and then to the Department for Culture, Media and Sport. So I’ve ended up contributing to the public sector after all.   Related: I thought I was blazing a trail for minorities in Whitehall. I was wrong    Being part of the public sector is an absolute privilege, but unfortunately that word privilege still rings true for too many of the wrong reasons. Recent research conducted by youth employment charity Elevation Networks found that an overwhelming 96.5% of the public sector’s senior leaders are white and, unfortunately, I can’t say that I was shocked by the revelation. In today’s multicultural world, it’s easy to assume that discrimination is a thing of the past. Sadly, it’s ever present, and our public sector is no stranger to it. It can still be an old boys’ club – like a party you didn’t get invited to – and an impenetrable maze for those who don’t know someone at the top. With just 3.5% of people at the top coming from non-white backgrounds, it’s easy to see why. That’s not to say that people from black and minority ethnic (BME) backgrounds aren’t attracted to the public sector full stop – quite the opposite. The Department of Health’s workforce as a whole is broadly representative of the population, with 17% of staff from BME backgrounds. But there are nearly ten times the number of BME employees in administrative roles (39%) as there are in Whitehall’s senior civil servant positions (4%). Compare this with tech entrepreneurs in the US: Indians hold some of the most powerful positions in some of the largest companies, including Microsoft, Google, Intel, Facebook, Cisco, Adobe… the list goes on. Clearly, we have a real problem with attracting and promoting diverse talent to the top. And this is a problem – for everyone. It’s a problem for young people who won’t be aiming for a career that could just be their passion, and for those of us in society that don’t benefit from their skills, talent and leadership.   Related: 'The right sort of female chap' – the story of women in Whitehall    This must be changed. That doesn’t mean creating an old boys’ network of our own (for a start, we need more women, too) but it does mean, that whoever we are and whatever position we’re in, we do everything in our power to educate, encourage and promote those around us, whatever their background. Parents and teachers ought to encourage young people to actively seek out roles in the public sector because they are jobs to be proud of, but also jobs that are within our grasp. What’s essential is that people don’t discount themselves for any role at any level because they are from a BME background. I hope that as we move forwards as a nation, the way can be paved for other individuals to achieve their full potential. Ajay Chowdhury is a non-executive director at the Department of Culture, Media and Sport This series aims to give a voice to the staff behind the public services that are hit by mounting cuts and rising demand, and so often denigrated by the press, politicians and public.
